results.title: An Interview with Brigadier John P.A. Deighton
results.brief_description: John Deighton admits that at 18, everyone believes that they are bulletproof but the adventure of war stops when people start dying. He believes that the instant replay effect and the televisation of the Vietnam War was a factor in its unpopularity. He remembers the poor treatment Vietnam vets received on their return and how unfair it was as they were just doing their job.

production_dates.notes: Workshop was in August 2009 but project completed in September 2009

results.title: An Interview with Billie Lindsay
results.brief_description: Billie had just gone through training as a nurse when she was whisked away to war. She tells how she was immediately signed up while waiting for a friend, her time in Malaya and considers the way we look at war today and how her time in the army stood her in good stead later on in life.

results.title: An Interview with Alf Argent
results.brief_description: When Alf finished school, World War II had started. He signed up but was not called up for service until after he graduated from Duntroon at age 18. Alf then tells the story of his journey, through the Korean War, the Vietnam War to training in Europe and how he got to see the effects of war first-hand. A distinguised man who led an extraordinary life.

Alf then tells the story of his journey, through the Korean War, the Vietnam War to training in Europe and how he got to see the effects of war first-hand. A distinguised man who led an extraordinary life.

results.title: Mountains of memories : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Four stories from people with a deep connection to the Victorian Alpine Country. From different backgrounds, they share their experiences of working, living and travelling to the Alpine country, the stories of ancestors who have mined and lived in the region and how the Alpine country has left an indeliable impression on their lives.
results.description: Four stories from people with a deep connection to the Victorian Alpine Country. results.title: In search of golden footprints
results.creator_credit: Andrew Swift and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Andrew Swift was raised in a small mining town in the foothills of the Victorian Alpine country. The more he learnt about the history of mining in the region, the more his interest in the remote areas of the Alps increased. Andrew’s exploration of the area has unearthed evidence of the long forgotton gold mines and the stories of the people who worked there.

results.title: The Honeymoon
results.creator_credit: Laurel Whitcroft (Allen) and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: My family has a tradition of holidaying at Mt Buffalo Chalet, that has continued through four generations. A family album of the holidays in the Victorian Alps taken initially by Laurel and her husband for their honeymoon, then the subsequent returns by the growing family throughout the decades.

results.title: Home in the high country
results.creator_credit: Trevor Larner and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Trevor Larner first discovered the Victorian high country as a teenager. He initially wanted to get to the highest point, but then fell in love with the vegetation and beauty of the Alpine region. Eventually he started working there maintaining infrastructure, building ski lodges and repairing the huts of the early pioneers. When Trevor went back to visit in 2008, it felt like he was coming home.

He initially wanted to get to the highest point, but then fell in love with the vegetation and beauty of the Alpine region. When Trevor went back to visit in 2008, it felt like he was coming home.

results.title: The Dulugar
results.creator_credit: James Hackell and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: My love of stories and my love of the bush grew at the same time. Stories bring the land to life. A story about a man’s connection to his Indigenous ancestors through the Victorian Alpine country and the stories that would pass through the generations, especially the one about the Dulugar, a fierce creature said to exist in the region, haunting campers with their red eyes and devil-like smell.

results.title: Beyond the Big Issue : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Nine of Melbourne’s homeless and disabled share the stories of their lives and talk about how The Big Issue has changed their circumstances. They also talk about their interests, friends, family, daily struggles and how working for the Big Issue has helped restore dignity to their lives.
results.title_for_label: Beyond the Big Issue : Digital Storytelling project

results.title: Running to stand still
results.brief_description: Adrian Bush tells the story of how, after spending most of his life on the move, he found friendship and a sense of belonging playing street soccer in Fitzroy, Melbourne, with others from the Big Issue team. Adrian was selected for the Australian street soccer team, which toured internationally, and appeared in an ABC documentary. His experiences with the Big Issue and street soccer have transformed Adrian’s life.
